title: Cat. 38  Aureus (Coin) Portraying Nero Claudius Drusus, A.D. 41/45

<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Nero Claudius Drusus  
A.D. 41/45, issued by Claudius (Tiberius Claudius Nero)  
Gold; diam. 1.9 cm; 7.72 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Head of N. Claudius Drusus left, laureate  
Inscribed: NERO CLAVDIVS DRVSVS GERMANICVS IMP  
Reverse: Equestrian statue atop triumphal arch, trophies and prisoners at each corner  
Inscribed: DE GERM (above and across lintel of arch)  
RIC I 69, BMCRE I 95; axis: 7:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4858

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Early in his reign Claudius (r. A.D. 41–54) issued coins commemorating his parents, Nero Claudius Drusus (see fig. 38.1) and Antonia Minor. This example celebrates the German exploits of Drusus, who in A.D. 9 found “a grave and a name” in that dangerous province. Like his brother Tiberius, who became emperor, Drusus was a stepson of Augustus and one of his best generals. He created several military bases along the Rhine. His achievement won him a posthumous grant by the Senate of the titles Imperator and Germanicus (conqueror of Germany), as attested by the obverse inscription, as well as the right of his offspring in perpetuity to use those names. In his youthful portrait he wears the laurel wreath of military victory; on the reverse, Claudius offers his father the triumph he was never able to enjoy in life. Claudius’s own achievements in Germany in the year 41 and his conquest of Britain in 43, also celebrated on his coinage, may have been the impetus for the minting of this coin. Because of the close family resemblance among Julio-Claudians—a resemblance that was carefully cultivated in artistic representations—numismatic portraits are of less help than one might wish in identifying the many unnamed sculptures of members of the Julio-Claudian family gracing the world’s museums.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Ovid, Fasti 1.597: “et mortem et nomen Druso Germania fecit.” Today he is called “Elder Drusus” to distinguish him from Julius Caesar Drusus, the son of Emperor Tiberius.

Including Mainz, where there remains a monument—Dio Cassius calls it a cenotaph—built in his memory by his soldiers: the so-called Drususstein. Dio Cassius, Roman History 55.2.

See Swan, Augustan Succession, p. 42.

Compare Daltrop, “Museo Gregoriano Profano.”
